title: Forget The S&P 500 - 3 Fantastic Dividend Stocks With Double-Digit Return Potential
body:
marketlan/iStock via Getty Images

Introduction

Most of my articles are about "big picture" developments. I'm not only doing this to use them as a foundation for stock picks but also because I believe that discussing major developments is sometimes more important than discussing individual stock picks.

I also want to provide value for people who may not like my stock picks to have info for their own stock selection.

Some big-picture developments we have frequently discussed are (some more than others):

The energy bull case.

Artificial intelligence.

A top-heavy S&P 500.

Inflation.

Supply chain re-shoring.

Biden/Biden picks.

Green transition.

Needless to say, a lot of these topics are in some way related. This includes the impact of artificial intelligence on energy demand and the composition of the S&P 500, which is something I want to discuss in this article.

The S&P 500 just exited the first half of this year. It returned 14%, which is the second-best first-half performance this century.

Speaking of this century, the number of record highs (31) in the first half of this year is also the second-highest number this century.

Bloomberg

Since the lows on October 12, 2022, the market has added $16 trillion in value, most of it coming from technology and communications services. The same goes for the first six months of this year.

Bloomberg

What's interesting is Nvidia (NVDA) was a huge outlier, adding more than 200 points to the S&P 500 in the first half, with a number of "big guys" adding more than 40% year-to-date.

Bloomberg

While this is great for people who simply own the S&P 500, it has created a very unusual situation, as the equal-weight S&P 500 has underperformed the market-weighted S&P 500 (the "normal" S&P 500) by the widest margin in the first six months of a year ever.

This is what the underperformance of the equal-weighted S&P 500 compared to the S&P 500 since October 12, 2022, looks like:

Bloomberg

As of June 27, the biggest six companies in the S&P 500 account for 31.4% of the S&P 500!

These companies are Microsoft (MSFT), Apple (AAPL), Nvidia, Amazon (AMZN), Meta Platforms (META), and Alphabet (GOOGL).

What do these companies have in common?

They all have turned into AI plays.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not "hating" on these companies. They all have phenomenal products, pristine balance sheets, and bright futures.

The problem I see is diversification. The S&P 500's purpose is to offer diversified exposure. Right now, it has turned into an AI play, with most sectors lagging behind.

If the AI rally runs into trouble, the S&P 500 is likely poised to underperform - especially because it is now valued at 21x earnings, indicating subdued returns in the years ahead (see the chart below).

JPMorgan

Again, I'm not making the case the AI rally is over. This is simply a risk/reward assessment. As much as I believe AI enthusiasm was justified, it's not something that will last forever, especially because expectations are now sky-high.

However, this does not mean the average investor is now looking at a high likelihood of subdued returns in the years ahead.

Because the S&P 500's surge was mainly fueled by tech, a lot of companies have been left in the dust - often with great valuations and potential.

In this article, I'll present three dividend stocks that all trade at very attractive valuations, have great business models, and come with either high income or consistent dividend growth.

I own one of them and have the other two on my watchlist.

Norfolk Southern (NSC) - A Struggling Giant With Tremendous Potential

Norfolk Southern was one of the first dividend stocks I bought, as I wanted to own a company with a good dividend growth track record, an ultra-wide moat, and the ability to benefit from secular growth like economic re-shoring.

Regarding its moat, headquartered in Atlanta, Georgia, Norfolk Southern is one of America's largest Class I railroads, which enjoys a duopoly with its peer CSX Corp. (CSX) in the Eastern third of the United States.

Association of American Railroads

Because of its dominant position, it enjoys a very wide moat, which is one of the reasons why it has consistently outperformed the S&P 500 and most non-rail transportation peers.

Unfortunately, the company's stock has been lackluster since early 2022, when it started to encounter a number of headwinds, including weaker economic growth, falling consumer sentiment (NSC is a major intermodal railroad), a derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, and ongoing operating challenges.

Data by YCharts

In other words, the company has somewhat lost its way, which was reflected in poor 1Q24 earnings, when the company reported 2% lower revenues, 1% higher expenses, and 6% lower operating income - adjusted for the East Palestine derailment.

Norfolk Southern Corporation

It now has an operating ratio of 69.9%, which is a horrible result.

With that said, I am a buyer of NSC, as I am a big fan of buying undervalued stocks with turnaround potential - especially in critical supply chains.

Pressured by activist investors, NSC is working hard to turn its business around, which includes cutting costs and improving rail operations.

Our strategy is designed to mirror the great success stories of the Canadian railroads who have recognized that PSR is about more than tearing a railroad down to its studs at slashing costs regardless of the fallout. As our Board member, Claude Mageau demonstrated when he was CEO of Canadian National, a PSR operating model, when part of a customer-focused balanced strategy, can deliver top-tier revenue growth and a sub-60 operating ratio. - NSC 1Q24 Earnings Call

Norfolk Southern Corporation

If the company is able to lower its operating ratio to 66% by the end of this year, it could massively improve investor confidence.

As we turn to the balance of the year, we will see our margins improve materially from here. We are finally starting to see excess service costs unwind and they will accelerate downward in Q2. That trajectory, along with the reduction in non-agreement headcount as well as other productivity initiatives leave us confident in a strong productivity story for Q2. - NSC 1Q24 Earnings Call

While I wait for this turnaround to get support from better economic growth, I enjoy a 2.5% dividend. This may not be a juicy yield. However, it comes with a 46% payout ratio and a five-year CAGR of 10.2%.

Over the past ten years, this dividend has risen by 137%. The share count has been reduced by 27%.

Data by YCharts

Currently, NSC trades at a blended P/E ratio of 18.2x.

Analysts expect a 1% EPS recovery in 2024, potentially followed by 17% and 14% growth in 2025 and 2026, respectively.

FAST Graphs

This paves the way for a fair price target of $275, 28% above its current price.

On a longer-term basis, I'm much more bullish, as I expect NSC to go back to its old glory, especially if it gets a much-needed tailwind from economic growth.

While I have been buying gradually, I'm going to be a much more aggressive buyer *if* NSC drops to or below $200.

Zoetis (ZTS) - Undervalued Dividend Growth

Zoetis has become one of my favorite healthcare stocks. The former Pfizer (PFE) spin-off has become the world's largest producer of vaccines, medicines, diagnostics, and similar for animals.

Zoetis Inc.

The company's portfolio covers eight core species and seven therapeutic areas and holds 15 blockbuster drugs among roughly 300 product lines.

With regard to patent loss risks, the average market life of key brands in its portfolio is 30 years, including anti-infectives, dermatology, vaccines, pain and sedation, and others.

Zoetis Inc.

What matters is that the company holds the number one market share in:

North America, Latin America, and Asia.

Dermatology and pet pain.

Companion animals, cattle, and fish.

It has also consistently outperformed its peers, growing revenues by 8% annually since its IPO in 2013.

Zoetis Inc.

Through 2033, the company expects to maintain consistent growth, as it believes its total addressable market will grow by 4-6% annually to at least $75 billion by 2033.

Zoetis Inc.

It also has consistently grown its margins, which boosted adjusted net income by 109% in the 2017-2023 period.

Zoetis Inc.

With that said, ZTS is down 12% year-to-date, which was triggered by the news that its arthritis drug, Librela, could be harmful. I discussed this in an article published on April 14, when I went with the title "Despite Lawsuit Risks: Why Zoetis Remains A Completing Investment."

Since then, shares have rebounded 15%, beating the 6% return of the S&P 500.

While lawsuit risks are always an issue in healthcare, I believe these fears are overblown, allowing investors to buy ZTS at attractive prices.

Currently yielding 1.0%, Zoetis comes with a payout ratio of 29% and a five-year CAGR of 22.7%. It also has outperformed the market by a wide margin over the past ten years.

Data by YCharts

Moreover, the company, which enjoys anti-cyclical demand, is currently trading at a blended P/E ratio of 31.3x, which is slightly below its normalized P/E ratio of 31.7x. While this may seem like a lofty valuation, analysts expect 8-10% annual EPS growth to last, potentially paving the road for 10-11% annual returns.

FAST Graphs

As such, I stick to my buy rating and believe ZTS offers a great risk/reward for dividend growth investors seeking healthcare exposure in a market with strong long-term secular tailwinds.

With that said, if you're looking for a higher yield, the next pick may be for you.

Suncor Energy (SU) - A Dirt-Cheap Canadian Oil Play

Suncor is the largest peer of my investment in Canadian Natural Resources (CNQ). The company is one of the largest operators in Canada's oil sands and one of my favorite picks for income and capital gains.

The company has a number of benefits that I'm looking for in an oil company, which include deep reserves (more than 25 years of low-cost reserves), efficient operations in oil sands, and an increasing focus on shareholder distributions.

Suncor Energy

My most recent article on Suncor was written on May 19, when I called it "One Of My Best Ideas In Energy." Since then, it held a special call in May when it presented its long-term outlook.

During this call, it committed to an additional C$3.3 billion per year in free cash flow by the end of 2026, which translates to significant cash generation and shareholder returns.

This improvement comes with a targeted reduction in the company's WTI breakeven by $10 per barrel, which massively improves its free cash flow potential.

Suncor Energy

Moreover, it has revised its net debt target for its 100% free cash flow payout to C$8 billion. That is down from C$9 billion. As I wrote in my prior article, expectations are for C$8.6 billion in net debt by the end of this year, which makes it likely that Suncor will reach its debt target next year.

This bodes well for shareholders, as the company aims to deliver over C$40 billion of AFFO (adjusted funds from operations) from 2024 to 2026, with a 10% compound annual growth rate, translating to a 15% growth rate on a per-share basis.

Suncor Energy

Currently yielding 4.2%, the company aims to grow its dividend by 3-5% annually, with most shareholder returns coming from buybacks.

Given the company's favorable production outlook, in 2026, it could generate north of C$8 billion in free cash flow at $75 WTI. That translates to 12% of its market cap. This bodes very well for buybacks and total returns!

Suncor Energy

With regard to production, the company plans to increase upstream production by over 100,000 barrels per day while keeping controllable costs flat, which could potentially result in an 8% decline in operating cost per barrel over the next three years.

Suncor Energy

As I believe oil has much more room to rise than $75 WTI, I consider Suncor to be a "hidden" Canadian gem, which is perfect for a wide range of investors, including income and buyback-focused investors.

Please note that Suncor is listed both in Toronto and New York.

Valuation-wise, Suncor currently trades at a blended P/OCF (operating cash flow) ratio of just 5.3x, making it one of the cheapest energy stocks on my radar.

Applying an 8.5x multiple, the company has a fair stock price of C$92 in Toronto, 76% above the current price. The same applies to New York-listed shares.

FAST Graphs

Needless to say, I believe SU has a lot of room to run the moment energy bulls return, making it one of my top picks in the sector.

Takeaway

The S&P 500 has surged, mainly driven by tech giants and AI enthusiasm. This concentration poses a risk if the AI boom slows.

It also left other promising sectors undervalued.

In this article, we discussed three compelling dividend stocks: Norfolk Southern, Zoetis, and Suncor Energy.

Each offers unique advantages, from Norfolk's potential turnaround in the rail industry and Zoetis's leadership in animal healthcare to Suncor's massive potential in the energy sector.

I believe these picks provide a great risk/reward in the dividend (growth) space and offer value in what has become a very challenging market.

title: Trump immunity ruling due for release in Supreme Court's final decision day
body:
Republican presidential candidate, former U.S. President Donald Trump speaks at a campaign rally at the Liacouras Center on June 22, 2024 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

The Supreme Court is poised Monday morning to release the final opinions of its term — including a ruling on whether former President Donald Trump is immune from criminal prosecution on federal election interference charges.

The decision by the high court, whose six-seat conservative majority includes three members nominated by Trump, will determine the fate of the high-stakes criminal case brought by special counsel Jack Smith.

Trump is charged in a four-count indictment with illegally conspiring to overturn his loss to President Joe Biden in the 2020 presidential election.

The case in Washington, D.C., federal court has been on pause while Trump argues that he is immune from prosecution for any official acts he performed while he was president.

This is developing news. Please check back for updates.

title: What Will Biden Donors Do Now?
body:
Donors still on edge

The shock waves from last week’s presidential debate are still reverberating, as President Biden and his aides sought to allay concerns from despondent Democrats and wealthy donors about his age and fitness for office.

Donors are increasingly becoming reconciled to Biden remaining the Democratic nominee even after Biden’s disastrous performance. But some in the party, and in the markets, are increasingly expecting Donald Trump to win in November.

Here’s the latest fallout from the debate. Seventy-two percent of registered voters don’t believe Biden has the mental and cognitive health to serve as president, according to a CBS News poll published Sunday, compared with 65 percent in early June.

With the odds for a Trump win rising after the debate, Wall Street analysts are recalculating what that could mean for the economy and the markets. Among their forecasts are a slowdown in growth and resurgence in inflation that could muddle the Fed’s interest rate policy, especially if Trump carries out his proposals for mass deportation of undocumented migrants and higher tariffs.
